basics.name: Johannes L. Hörmann
basics.label: Scientist
basics.summary: Computational tribologist, data explorer, and sinoenthusiast.

work.name: livMatS Cluster of Excellence, University of Freiburg, Germany
work.summary: Development and implementation of Research Data Management (RDM) policy. Development and provision of RDM tooling.

work.name: Surface Design Solutions
work.summary: Co-founder and CTO of Start Up Surface Design Solutions

work.name: Academic examination office, a joint institution of the German Embassy’s cultural department and the German Academic Exchange Service (DAAD)
work.summary: Conducting interviews for plausibility verification of academic records.

education.institution: Simulation, Dept. of Microsystems Engineering (IMTEK), University of Freiburg
courses: Dissertation: Friction of Adsorption Films with Reproducible Molecular Dynamics
Master thesis (grade 1.3, German scale): Computational Modeling of Potential-Controlled Dodecyl Sulfate Ion Adsorption at the Aqueous and Non-aqueous SDS Solution – Stainless Steel Interface
Bachelor thesis (grade 1.0, German scale): Large Scale Parallel Simulation of EPR Lineshape Spectra

DAAD Annual Scholarship for Exchange Studies
awards.summary: For studies at Tsinghua University, Beijing, China.

awards.title: DAAD Annual Scholarship for Language Studies / Huayu Enrichment Scholarship
awards.awarder: German Academic Exchange Service (DAAD) and Ministry of Education, Taiwan
awards.summary: For language studies at National Sun Yat-Sen University, Kaohsiung, Taiwan.

publications.name: Zur Elektrody/namik bewegter Körper
publications.summary: It concerned an interpretation of the Michelson–Morley experiment and the properties of light and time. Special relativity incorporates the principle that the speed of light is the same for all inertial observers regardless of the state of motion of the source.

publications.name: Über einen die Erzeugung und Verwandlung des Lichtes betreffenden heuristischen Gesichtspunkt
publications.summary: In the second paper, he applied the quantum theory to light to explain the photoelectric effect. In particular, he used the idea of light quanta (photons) to explain experimental results, but stressed the importance of the experimental results. The importance of his work on the photoelectric effect earned him the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1921.

publications.name: Die Grundlage der allgemeinen Relativitätstheorie
publications.summary: The publication of the theory of general relativity made him internationally famous. He was professor of physics at the universities of Zurich (1909–1911) and Prague (1911–1912), before he returned to ETH Zurich (1912–1914).

projects.name: Quantum Computing
projects.summary: Quantum computing is the use of quantum-mechanical phenomena such as superposition and entanglement to perform computation. Computers that perform quantum computations are known as quantum computers.
